revised_title: Observation of the Summer Solstice in 1812 at the Royal Observatory
tldr: The Astronomer Royal, John Pond, observed the Summer Solstice of 1812 at the Royal Observatory using a new circular instrument. He measured the sun's position without relying on a plumb-line or level, and the results were accurate within one-tenth of a second. The observations were subject to uncertainty regarding astronomical refraction, and Pond used Dr. Bradley's data for this calculation.
